L1.brief_rationale: The defining European cultural rebirth of the 14th–17th centuries is universally known and appears in virtually every general-education curriculum.
Among the most famous art movements worldwide; Monet, Renoir, and Degas are household names recognized by any educated person.
Widely recognized stylistic period associated with dramatic grandeur and famous works by Caravaggio and Rembrandt, covered in general surveys.
One of the most famous artists in Western history, universally recognizable through the Sistine Chapel and David.
The archetypal Renaissance genius whose name and works — the Mona Lisa, The Last Supper — are known globally.
Instantly recognizable style of medieval cathedrals with pointed arches and stained glass, familiar to any educated person.
Major early-20th-century movement associated with Picasso and Braque, widely recognized in popular culture and general education.
Broad cultural and artistic movement of the late 18th–19th centuries encountered in literature, music, and visual-art surveys alike.
Among the most celebrated painters in Western art history; his name and self-portraits are universally recognized.
One of the most reproduced and recognized paintings in the world, by Van Gogh; known even to those with no formal art training.
Major 20th-century movement known through Dalí's melting clocks and Magritte's imagery; widely referenced in popular culture.
The most iconic ancient Greek building, a global symbol of classical civilization known to any educated person.
The most recognized monument of ancient Roman architecture, a world-famous landmark universally known.

L2.brief_rationale: Key Classical and Renaissance sculptural pose requiring specific art-historical vocabulary; recognizable to students of art history.
Specific technique of light-dark contrast central to Baroque and Renaissance painting; standard art-history student vocabulary.
Specific wall-painting technique defining medieval and Renaissance mural art; requires knowledge of historical materials.
Named altarpiece format common in medieval and Renaissance religious art; requires familiarity with devotional painting conventions.
Specific Post-Impressionist technique of painting with dots, associated with Seurat; requires art-student level knowledge of 19th-century movements.
Distinct late-Renaissance style characterized by elongation and artifice; requires the ability to distinguish it from High Renaissance.
Period grouping Cézanne, Van Gogh, and Gauguin after Impressionism; requires awareness of stylistic evolution in late-19th-century art.
Elegant decorative style of 18th-century France associated with Watteau and Fragonard; requires familiarity with European court culture.
Fundamental format of religious painting in medieval and Renaissance Europe; requires knowledge of the devotional function of art.
Egg-based painting medium dominant before oil paint; requires technical knowledge of historical art materials.
Early 20th-century German-led movement distorting form for emotional effect; requires ability to distinguish it from contemporaneous styles.
18th–19th-century revival of Greco-Roman ideals in art and architecture; requires knowledge of the Enlightenment cultural context.
Practice of painting outdoors central to Impressionism; requires art-vocabulary knowledge linking technique to movement.

L3.brief_rationale: Leonardo's specific technique of blending tones without hard edges; requires working knowledge of Renaissance painterly technique and theory.
The 1863 exhibition of rejected works that helped launch modern art; requires understanding of institutional gatekeeping and the birth of Impressionism.
Wagner-derived concept of the total work of art synthesizing media; requires cross-disciplinary knowledge linking music, theater, and visual art.
Precise topographical painting of city views, especially Venetian; requires knowledge of 18th-century Italian painting and the Grand Tour.
Symbolic still-life genre meditating on mortality; requires understanding of Dutch Golden Age painting conventions and iconography.
Dutch abstract movement of Mondrian and van Doesburg reducing form to grids and primary colors; requires understanding of early-20th-century European abstraction.
Extreme Baroque chiaroscuro associated with Caravaggio; requires ability to distinguish it from more general light-dark effects in painting.
Nazi propaganda exhibition attacking modernism in 1937; requires knowledge of the intersection of ideology, censorship, and modern European art.
The Barbizon school's outdoor landscape painting in mid-19th-century France prefigured Impressionism; requires contextual knowledge of French art institutions.
Viennese applied-arts workshop bridging Art Nouveau and modernism; requires knowledge of early 20th-century Austro-German design reform movements.
Art movement depicting working-class life and social conditions; requires understanding of 19th–20th-century ideological currents in European art.
Perspectival technique of depicting a form at an extreme angle; requires working knowledge of Renaissance spatial illusionism and figure drawing.

L4.brief_rationale: Renaissance theoretical debate on the hierarchy of painting versus sculpture, requiring deep engagement with early modern art theory and Vasari's writings.
Wölfflin's formalist framework of Renaissance vs. Baroque visual categories is foundational art-historical methodology, requiring advanced historiographic knowledge.
16th-century Florentine vs. Venetian theoretical debate over line vs. color as the foundation of painting; requires deep knowledge of Renaissance art theory.
Traces of earlier underdrawing or compositional changes visible in aged paintings; requires knowledge of technical art history and conservation science.
Panofsky's method of interpreting deeper symbolic meaning in images beyond iconography; requires advanced familiarity with art-historical hermeneutics.
Scholarly debate over the original painted surfaces of Greek and Roman marble sculpture, challenging assumptions of 'white antiquity'; requires deep historiographic knowledge.
Underdrawing in red pigment on the arriccio layer of a fresco revealed by detachment; requires specialized technical knowledge of fresco preparation.
Riegl's concept of an immanent 'will-to-form' driving stylistic change; foundational and contested in art historiography, requiring advanced theoretical grounding.
Rhetorical description of a visual artwork in words, from Homer to Keats; requires knowledge of classical rhetoric, art theory, and literature's relationship to visual art.
Aby Warburg's concept of recurring gestural formulas carrying emotional memory across epochs; central to iconological studies and advanced visual-culture scholarship.
The 17th–18th-century educational tour of Europe's classical sites shaping aristocratic taste and the art market; requires knowledge of its long-term effects on collecting and Neoclassicism.
Historiographic division of Italian Renaissance painting into 15th- and 16th-century phases with distinct stylistic traits; requires deep working knowledge of periodization debates.
